dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An afternoon in late November, the leaves have left the trees, and the early darkness of a winter dusk approaches The garden is long and narrow, guarded on either side by high brick wall. At one end stands the rear of a three-st brick townhouse; at the other, a one story brick building CLASSICAL MUSIC is heard in the distance. A MAN, handsome dressed in a well-tailored suit of the 1920's, works in t garden. A gardener's apron protects his suit from the ear as he turns the loam along one of the walkways. He works slowly,-precisely, obviously engrossed in his surrounding This man is called CHANCE. Chance stops working for a moment, takes a pocket watch f inside his coat, checks the time. He looks to the darkeni skies, returns the watch to his pocket. As Chance starts toward the one story brick building, he takes a spotless from his apron pocket and wipes the dirt from the tines o his pitchfork.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sound of the music increases as Chance enters the gar from the garden. A gleaming 1921 TOURING CAR is revealed he walks through the garage and leans the pitchfork again wall. Chance takes a neatly folded cover from a shelf, carefully puts it over the car. When he finishes covering car for the night, Chance picks up the pitchfork, leaves garage through a side entry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Potting Room is filled with the tools of the gardener everything arranged in an orderly fashion. Rows of small are on tables, young plants sprouting from some of them. small, 1940's table model black-and-white TV rests on a shelf. It is playing, tuned to the BOSTON POPS ORCHESTRA. Attached to the front of the screen is a wheel containing colored gels. The wheels spins, creates an early form of color TV. As Chance enters, his attention is on the television set. He watches it as he oils the tines of the pitchfork and puts it away. Chance turns off the TV and leaves the room, but the sound of the Boston Pops continu

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A room adjacent to the Potting Room. A large screen remot control color television set dominates the room. It is on tuned to the Boston Pops. In contrast to the new TV, the of the room is sparsely but tastefully decorated with expensive furniture of the twenties. There are no books, magazines, newspapers or reading matter of any kind to be seen. Chance comes in, watches the TV with a detached gaz he removes his apron. He changes the channel with the rem control as he puts his apron and the pitchfork rag into a laundry bag. He takes off his suit jacket, hangs it in th closet where it is accompanied by several others, all of quality. Chance changes the channel once again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chance, wearing a different suit and carrying the laundry bag, crosses from the rear building to the main house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The interior of the main house has the mustiness of age, warmth of oak. White dropcloths and sheets cover all of t furniture. Chance enters, walks through the hallway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A large dropcloth is over the dining room table and chair It is neatly folded back at one end, leaving one chair an place setting uncovered. A small portable color TV is nex the place setting. Chance enters, puts his laundry bag on a covered table ne the doorway. He sits at the dining room table, turns on t TV, and carefully unfolds his napkin, puts it on his lap he watches the screen. LOUISE, an elderly black maid, ent with a tray of food and Chance's clean laundry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sets dinner before Chance)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Evening, Chance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (slowly, perfect diction, no accent of any kind)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Good evening, Louise. Louise sets Chance's clean clothes on the small table, pi up his laundry bag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... The Old Man is getting weaker, Chance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (begins to eat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm afraid he's slippin' a bit with every hour that goes by... Chance, his manners impeccable, concentrates on the TV as eats. A buzzer SOUNDS, Louise looks upstairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Back up those stairs - damn... That Man's needin' me more and more just before he never needs me again...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (still watches TV)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is his back feeling better? Louise gives Chance a look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Gobbledegook... You and your gobbledegook. You're gonna be the death of me yet, Chance... (she turns to leave)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Unless those stairs are... The Good Lord's liable to snatch up two unwillin' souls at the same time if I keep on trampin' up those stairs... I don't want none of that... Louise disappears through the doorway. Chance continues t eat and watch TV.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chance is asleep, lying on his back. His eyes slowly open and, with no change of expression, he sits up and turns o the TV with the remote control. Chance gets out of bed, g to the dresser and takes his pocket watch out of a drawer checks the time. He crosses to the closet, his eyes never straying from an early morning show on television. He put a bathrobe and leaves the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chance enters, turns on the TV with the spinning color wh then waters a few of the pots with a sprinkling can. He t off the TV and exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chance comes into the garage, takes the cover off of the touring car, folds it and puts it on a shelf. He leaves t garage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chance returns to his room, changes channels on the television, takes off his robe and hangs it back up in th closet, then goes into the bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A light snow is falling. The door to the small building opens, Chance peeks out, then goes back inside. A few sec pass and Chance reappears, this time with an umbrella. Smartly dressed in suit and tie, he crosses to the main house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chance opens the door, shakes off and closes the umbrella before entering. He hangs the umbrella on a doorknob, the heads for the dining room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Repeating his ritual, Chance enters the dining room, sits turns on the TV, carefully spreads his napkin on his lap. watches the screen for a moment, then turns, expecting Louise. She doesn't appear, so he turns back, watches TV. After a few beats, Chance hears Louise's footsteps hurryi down the stairs. She comes into the dining room, visibly distraught. Chance looks up, smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good morning, Louise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (out of breath)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's dead, Chance! The Old Man's dead!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (flatly, turns back to TV)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... I see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Must of happened durin' the night, I don't know... Lord, he wasn't breathin' and as cold as a fish. I touched him, just to see, and you believe me, Chance - that's doin' more than I get paid to do... Then I just covered him up, pulled the sheet over his head...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nodding)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. I've seen that done.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then I got the hell out of that room and called the doctor and I think I woke him probably, he wasn't any too alert. He just said, 'Yeah, he's been expectin' it and said he'd send somebody over...' Lord, what a mornin'!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (watches news, flashes of season's first snowfall)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Yes, Louise, it's snowing in the garden today. Have you looked outside and seen the snow? It's very white. A beat of silence from Louise, then anger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dammit, Boy! Is that all you got to say? More gobbledegook?  (Chance smiles, is silent)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That Old Man's layin' up there dead as hell and it just don't make any difference to you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with a smile, accepting death)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Louise. I have seen it often. It happens to old people.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, ain't that the truth...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. It is. Louise throws back the cover from a chair next to Chance sits, softening a bit toward him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Lord, Chance - I don't know what I was expectin' from you... I'm sorry for yellin' like I did... No sir, I just don't know what I was expectin' ...  (Chance doesn't react, watches TV)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... I 'spose I'd better gather up some breakfast for you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a turn to her)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I'm very hungry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (rises, looks upstairs)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, no more stewin' those prunes every mornin', that's somethin', I guess...  (she starts out, stops by the door)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... what are you goin' to do now, Chance?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gazing at TV)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going to work in the garden. Louise gives Chance a long look, then turns to leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as she goes)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... I'll get you some eggs. Chance nods in approval, then changes the channel on the

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An enclosed stairway. Chance enters, proceeds up the stai

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chance comes out of a doorway adjoining the main staircas He moves off down the hall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The furniture in this room is not covered with sheets but Old Man is. There is a polite knock at the door, then Cha enters the room. As Chance moves slowly to the Old Man's we sense a feeling of respect from Chance, as well as a b of curiosity. Chance stands by the side of the bed for a moment, then he reaches down and gently pulls the sheet b from the Old Man's face. He touches the man's forehead, lightly, briefly, then replaces the sheet. Chance moves t the TV (like the one in his own room) and turns it on. He sits in an easy chair next to the Old man's bed and watch movie from the early forties. Chance puts an arm out, res it on the Old Man's covered body. With the other, he chan the channels with the remote control. He returns to the channel with the forties movie and seem become absorbed in a scene in which a gentleman tips his to a lady. The scene seems to have 'sunk into' his mind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It has stopped snowing. Chance, wearing a hat, the garden apron over his suit and boots, putters in the garden. Lou comes out of the main house. She is dressed warmly, a sca over her head, a heavy coat. Chance sees her, tips his ha Louise exactly like the man he saw on television.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Well, ain't you the gentleman this mornin'... (a pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... gotta go now, Chance...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (resumes working)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're gonna need somebody, someone's gotta be around for you, boy...  (he keeps working)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... You oughta find yourself a lady, Chance...  (she smiles slightly, with caring)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I guess it oughta be an old lady, 'cause you ain't gonna do a young one any good, not with that little thing of yours...  (she reaches out, puts a hand on his shoulder)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... You're always gonna be a little boy, ain't you?  (he smiles, keeps working)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Goodbye, Chance... Louise gives his shoulder a squeeze, turns and moves towa the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as she goes)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goodbye, Louise. Louise waves as she enters the townhouse. Chance tips his once again as she disappears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Louise enters the hallway, picks up a couple of suit case waiting by the door. She stops as she sees TWO MEN in whi carrying a stretcher down the main staircase. She notices ease with which they bring the Old Man's body down the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... He used to be a big man... 'Spose he wasted away to about nothin'...  (a beat - then she talks to the body of the old Man)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... I guess I'll be goin' off to find me some folks, Old Man... I'm not batty enough to stay around this neighborhood any longer... The stretcher bearers move to the front door. Louise step front of them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to stretcher bearers)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait up! I'm goin' out that door first. Louise takes one more look at the covered body, then open the front door, leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The TV plays offstage as Chance washes up in the bathroom finishes, comes into the bedroom, takes a pair of house slippers from his closet, turns off the television and le the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chance, carrying his slippers, crosses through the layer fresh snow to the townhouse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chance, wearing the slippers, enters and sits at his plac He turns on the TV, puts the napkin on his lap. He watche for a moment, then turns, looks for Louise. She does not appear so he resumes watching TV. He changes channels, vi a wildly exciting FOOTBALL game. At a peak in the excitem he again switches channels. Chance watches TV News covera of the PRESIDENT of the United States greeting foreign dignitaries at the White House. CLOSE SHOTS on television reveal that the President uses two-handed handshake when meeting his guests. Unconscious Chance grips one hand with the other, the scene on TV see to have 'sunk into' his mind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A key is heard in the lock. The door opens and THOMAS FRANKLIN and SALLY HAYES enter. Franklin, an attorney, is his late thirties, carries a large briefcase. Hayes is younger, attractive, also an attorney. She totes a briefc has the look of a modern, liberated woman. Hayes appears be surprised at the interior of the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looks around)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... This is another world, Tom - I never would have believed it...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah... He and my father used to ride together back in the thirties... Fox hunting... Before I was born...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Would you take me on a tour?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gladly...  (he smiles)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... The safe is in Mr. Jennings' bedroom, that'll be stop number one. Franklin puts a hand on Hayes' shoulder as they,go off do the hall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chance still watches TV, waits for Louise to serve him. Franklin and Hayes appear in the doorway of the dining ro They are both surprised to see Chance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Why... Hello, we thought we heard something...  (moves to Chance, hand outstretched)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm Thomas Franklin. Chance remains seated, takes Franklin's hand warmly in bo of his like the President did on TV.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Thomas... I'm Chance, the gardener.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... The gardener?  (thinks it's a joke, laughs)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Yes, of course... Mr. Chance, this is Ms. Hayes. Hayes moves to shake Chance's hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Chance, I'm very pleased to meet you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (doesn't rise, again shakes with both hands)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. Chance turns back to the TV and Hayes and Franklin exchan looks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (after an uneasy pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... We're with Franklin, Jennings and Roberts, the law firm handling the estate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a smile, totally at ease)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Thomas - I understand. Another period of silence. Franklin and Hayes seem perple

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Are you waiting for someone? An appointment?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. I'm waiting for my lunch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your lunch? You have a luncheon appointment here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. Louise will bring me lunch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Louise?... The maid?... (a look to Hayes)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But she should have left earlier today...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiles at Hayes)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... You've quite a sense of humor, Mr. Chance - but all kidding aside, may I ask just what you are doing here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I live here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You live here? (a look to Hayes)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... We don't have any record of that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. It's very cold outside today, isn't it, Thomas?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... How long have you been living here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ever since I can remember, since I was a child.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (doubting)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Since you were a child?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Thomas. I have always been here. I have always worked in the garden.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Then you really are a gardener?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your appearance doesn't suggest that at all, Mr. Chance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you have any proof of your employment, Mr. Chance - any checks from the deceased, any contracts or documents?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How were you compensated for these duties you say you performed?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Compensated...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How were you paid?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was given meals, and a home...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about money?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I never needed money. Franklin steps to the TV, turns it off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Chance, perhaps you could show us some identification with your address -- a Driver's License, a credit card, checkbook?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I do not have any of those.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then how about medical records? Could you give us the name of your doctor, or your dentist?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have no need for a doctor or dentist. I have never been ill. I have never been allowed outside of this house, and, except for Joe, I have never had any visitors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Joe? Who's Joe?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (turns TV back on)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe Saracini. He was a mason that did some repairs on the brickwork at the rear of the house. That was in 1952.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (changes channels)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. I remember when he came. He was very fat and had short hair and showed me some pictures from a funny little book.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some pictures...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. Of men and women.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Chance, that was twenty-seven years ago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes and the Old Man used to come to my garden. He would read and rest there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come now, Mr. Jennings had been bedridden for thirty-five years, since he fractured his spine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Thomas, that is correct. Then he stopped visiting my garden.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... We shall need some proof of your having resided here, Mr. Chance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have me, I am here. What more proof do you need? Franklin and Hayes exchange looks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chance puts on his snow-boots as Franklin and Hayes conti their questioning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you served in the Army?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, Thomas. But I have seen the Army on television.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How about taxes, Mr. Chance, surely you must have paid taxes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Chance picks up his slippers and leads the attorneys outs

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chance describes his garden with pride as they walk towar the rear building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (points)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Those trees were very young when I first arrived.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you related to the deceased, Mr. Chance?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I don't think so. And I have planted and shaped all the hedges, and in the springtime you will be able to see my flowers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Might you have a birth certificate, Mr. Chance?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. (points to wall)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's where Joe fixed the bricks. They arrive at the rear building and Chance opens the doo the garage. Franklin and Hayes follow him inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Franklin and Hayes are taken aback by the touring car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (admires car)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Do you drive this, Mr. Chance?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, Thomas. I have never been in an automobile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (amazed)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You never been in a car? Chance is silent for a moment, he blushes slightly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Well... From time to time I did sit in it... Just in here... It hasn't been outside since the Old Man hurt himself. (he turns)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I live in here. Chance moves toward his room, Franklin and Hayes follow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chance sits on the bed to remove his boots as Hayes and Franklin inspect the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Old Man gave me nice television sets, this one has remote control. (he turns it on with the remote)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He has one just like it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Chance, the fact remains that we have no information of your having any connection with the deceased.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I understand. Chance puts on his slippers, crosses to the closet, opens door. It is filled with men's wear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am allowed to go to the attic and select any of the Old Man's suits. They all fit me very well. I can also take his shirts, shoes and coats.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is quite amazing how those clothes have come back into style.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. I have seen styles on television.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (getting back to business)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are your plans now, Mr. Chance?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I would like to stay and work in my garden. Chance turns to watch TV. Franklin takes Hayes to a side the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... What do you make of all this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I really don't know, Tom - he seems so honest and simple... In a way, he's quite charming...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looks at Chance)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Yeah...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... It's very bizarre - I don't know what to think...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well... He's either very, very bright or very, very dense - he's hard to figure... (he unzips briefcase)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Let's just keep everything legal. Franklin takes out some papers, approaches Chance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Chance, assuming what you say is the truth, I would like to know what sort of claim you are planning to make against the deceased's estate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (does not understand)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm fine, Thomas. The garden is a healthy one. There is no need for a claim.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good. That's good. Then if you would please sign a paper to that effect. Franklin hands the release to Chance but Chance does not it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, Thomas. I don't know how to sign.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come now, Mr. Chance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiles)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have no claim, Thomas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you won't sign, correct?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Correct.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very well, Mr. Chance - if you insist on dragging this matter on... But I must inform you this house will be closed tomorrow at noon. If indeed, you do reside here, you will have to move out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Move out? I don't understand, Thomas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think you do, Mr. Chance. However, I will reiterate, this house is closed and you must leave... (he gives Chance his business card)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Call me if you change your mind about signing. (turns to Hayes)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C'mon, Sally - let's grab a bite...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a smile to Chance)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good day, Mr. Chance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (returns smile)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good day, Sally. Chance watches as they leave, then puts Franklin's card o desk without ever looking at it and turns to stare at television.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A large attic filled with the Old Man's possessions of th past. Chance enters, turns on an old black-and-white TV w a magnifying lens attached to the front. As it plays, he selects a fine leather suitcase from several, takes a han made suit from a long rack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The TV is on as Chance packs his belongings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chance, very nicely dressed, comes out of the rear buildi carrying his suitcase. He stops on occasion to inspect hi garden as he walks toward the townhouse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chance is reluctant to open the front door. After some hesitation, he gathers up his courage, opens it and steps outside, closing the door behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chance stops short on the front steps; the townhouse is situated in a decaying ghetto. The snow is a dirty grey, houses adjoining have their win shattered, are smeared with grafitti. Chance tries to ret to the safety of the townhouse, but the door is locked. H stands on the steps for a moment, then moves to the trash laden sidewalk. He stops, ponders which way to go, finall makes up his mind and moves off to his left.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The buildings are crumbling, rusted out cars line the str A group of Black people huddle together in threadbare stu furniture on the sidewalk, a fire burning between them fo warmth. Chance rounds the corner, walks up to them. He st by them, smiles. They stare back, no sign of friendship i their faces. Chance nods politely to them, then walks awa down the sidewalk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A group of eight to ten hard-core ghetto youths hang out corner. Other passersby give them a wide berth, they are unapproachable. Chance nears the group, approaches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (friendly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Excuse me, would you please tell me where I could find a garden to work in? They turn to him as one, silent, amazed that this White trespasser would intrude on their jiving.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (after a beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... There is much to be done during the winter, I must start the seeds for the spring, I must work the soil... One of the Black youths, LOLO, interrupts Chance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What you growin', man? The leader of the gang, ABBAZ, shuts up Lolo with an elbo and moves menacingly forward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nose to nose with Chance)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... What you doin' here, boy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I had to leave my garden. I want to find another.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bullshit. Who sent you here, boy? Did that chickenshit asshole Raphael send you here, boy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Thomas Franklin told me that I had to leave the Old Man's house, he's dead now, you know...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dead, my ass! Now get this, honkie - you go tell Raphael that I ain't takin' no jive from no Western Union messenger! You tell that asshole, if he got somethin' to tell me to get his ass here himself!  (edges closer to Chance)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got that, boy? Chance smiles at Abbaz and reaches into his pocket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. I understand.  (he takes out his remote control TV changer)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I see Raphael I will tell him. Chance points the changer at Abbaz and clicks it three ti tries to change the picture. Abbaz immediately pulls out switchblade, whips the blade open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (holds knife at Chance)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, move, honkie! Before I cut your white ass! Chance, disappointed that the changer did not work, retur it to his pocket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. Of course. (as he leaves)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good day. Abbaz, Lolo and the gang watch him go, then begin to buzz with excitement: "Who the fuck died?" "Why'd he pull that changer on us, man?" "The Old Man died, must be Papa Joe! "He's some weird honkie, man."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Bulletin board affixed to a storefront in Chinatown. Ch gazes at the notes pinned to it, written in Chinese. Smil he turns from it, walks on through the area.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A street lined with adult book stores, X-rated movies and strip joints. An elderly Black woman approaches carrying bag of groceries. Chance steps in front of the woman, sto her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm very hungry now. Would you please bring me my lunch? The woman looks up to Chance, becomes very frightened. Sh turns and half-runs into a sleazy bar for safety. Chance watches after her for a moment, then continues along.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chance stands looking through a chain-link fence watching some teenage boys playing basketball. He bangs on the fen calls to them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have seen your game! I have watched Elvin Hayes play it many times! They call him "Big E!" The boys ignore him, Chance walks away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chance walks down the center meridian of a divided street seems oblivious to the automobiles passing on either side the background can be seen the Washington Monument.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chance seems stumped on which way to go. He looks up one street, then the other, has no idea where they lead. He turns, looks behind him and sees a large statue of Benito Juarez pointing. Chance smiles and goes off in the direct that Benito points.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tourists are gathered around gaping through the fence at White House. Chance is turned the other way, inspecting the branches o dying tree. Chance moves to a POLICEMAN standing nearby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me... (points to tree)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... That tree is very sick. It should be cared for. The Policeman looks at the tree, then at Chance, figures man dressed that well must be important.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes sir. I'll report it right away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. That would be a good thing to do. Good day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good day. The Policeman takes out his walkie-talkie as Chance walks away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A fashionable area. Expensive shops, well-kept streets an sidewalks. A television store has caught Chance's eye. He stands by the display window, looks in at a dozen or so c TVs, all turned on, playing various channels. A video cam points outward from a corner of the window and is focused the sidewalk to allow potential customers to see themselv live on an Advent TV. Chance is intrigued by his own imag He poses, lifts one arm, then the other to make sure that is really him on television. He moves forward, smiles, th moves slowly backward, notices himself become smaller on screen. He steps back off the curb, frowns as his likenes disappears from frame on the Advent. Standing between two parked cars, Chance takes out his remote control, clicks at the Advent. Four or five other sets in the window chan channels, but he does not reappear on the giant screen. A does this, the car to his,left, a large, American-made limousine, backs up. The car bumps Chance, pins him again the car to his right. Chance cries out in pain, drops his suitcase, his changer, and bangs his hand on the trunk of limo. The chauffeur, DAVID, and the liveryman, JEFFREY, immediately jump from the car, run back to Chance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm very sorry, sir... I... David and Jeffrey reach out to help, but Chance is wedged solidly between the two cars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in pain)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... I can't move... My leg...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (rushes back to limo)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... My Lord...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is terrible, sir -  I hope you're not badly injured...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. I'm not badly injured. But my leg is very sore. David pulls the car forward, freeing Chance. A few bystan begin to gather as Jeffrey helps Chance to the sidewalk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you walk? It's not broken, is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (leans against limo, holds leg)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's very sore. David gets out of the car, comes back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perhaps I should call an ambulance. A BYSTANDER interrupts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somebody ought to call the police!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looks over, smiles)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's no need for police, it's just my leg. During this, the rear door of the limo opens and EVE RAND steps out. Eve is in her late thirties, has the look of a traditional New England lady. She watches as Jeffrey tend Chance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think we should call anyone just yet, it may not even be all that serious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (obviously hurting)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I agree.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's have a look, do you mind?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course. I would like to look. Chance bends, raises his trouser leg. A red-bluish swolle bruise, three inches in diameter, is forming on his calf.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's starting to swell, is it painful?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. Eve moves closer to Chance, looks at the bruise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Chance)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Won't you let us do something for you? Your leg should be examined, we could take you to a hospital.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiles at Eve)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's no need for a hospital.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why, there certainly is. You must see a doctor, I insist on it. Please, let us take you. Eve turns to get back into the limo. David goes with her hold the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm terribly sorry, Mrs. Rand, I never saw the man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I don't think it was anyone's fault, David.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, ma'am. Chance is hesitant about getting in the car. Jeffrey offe helping hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've never ridden in an automobile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I assure you, sir, David is a very careful driver. Please, won't you let us take you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looks at the car, then decides)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Yes. You can take me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very good. Jeffrey assists Chance into the rear seat of the limo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as he gets in)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... My suitcase.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes sir. I'll take care of that. Jeffrey closes the door, goes back to pick up Chance's suitcase, does not notice the remote control. As Jeffrey Chance's bag into the trunk, we see the personalized lice plate "RAND l."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chance and Eve settle in the back seat. As they talk, Dav starts up the limo, Jeffrey joins him in front and the li pulls out into traffic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hope you're comfortable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. I am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These can be such trying situations everyone seems to make such a to-do over a simple little accident. Of course, they can be very frightening, and I must apologize for David, he's never had an accident before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. He's a very careful driver.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Why, yes, he is... Is your leg feeling any better?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's feeling better, but it's still very sore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see. (a thought)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Say, would you mind seeing our family doctor?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (doesn't understand)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your family doctor?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. My husband has been very ill. His doctor and nurses are staying with us. Those hospitals can be so impersonal - why, it might be hours before you are treated...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I agree.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine, it will save a lot of unnecessary fuss and it will be so much more pleasant for you... (leans forward)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David, we'll just go on home. Jeffrey, would you call and let them know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes ma'am. Eve presses a button, the glass partition closes. As the window rolls up behind him, Jeffrey dials the limo teleph There is a moment of silence. Eve, still a bit on edge fr the accident and feeling a bit uncomfortable with a stran in the car, presses another button. The limo's bar moves revealing a row of decanters and glasses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you care for a drink?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. Thank you. As Eve pours cognac into a monogrammed crystal glass, Cha notices the limo's TV set.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I would like to watch television.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a bit surprised)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh? Certainly... She hands Chance the cognac, turns on the TV.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, by the way - I'm Eve Rand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Eve.  Chance takes a sip of the cognac, is not accustomed to alcohol, coughs. There is another moment of silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: May I ask your name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with a slight cough)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My name is Chance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pardon me, was that Mr. Chance?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (still indistinct)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. I'm a gardener.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh... Mr. Gardiner... Mr. Chauncey Gardiner... You're not related to Basil and Perdita Gardiner are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, Eve. I'm not related to Basil and Perdita.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. Well, they're just a wonderful couple, we've been friends for years. We visit their island quite often. Chance reaches out to change the channel on the TV, sudde realizes he doesn't have his remote control. He starts go through his pockets, searches for it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you lose something?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. I lost my remote control.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh... Well, I'm very sorry... Another pause, Chance reaches out, changes channels on TV

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... I'll feel so relieved after Dr. Allenby examines your leg. After that, David can run you on home, or to your office or wherever you'd prefer...  (Chance still watches TV)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Is there anything special you would like to watch?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I like to watch. This is fine. Chance watches the news. Eve sips on her cognac as David eases the limo out of the city of Washington.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The limo approaches, then turns into the entrance-way of Rand Estate. Two guards stand on either side of the open gate, salute as the car passes through.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The drive runs alongside a stream, then turns and crosses large meadow. The limousine passes, still no sign of the house. It is a very, very long driveway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chance is glued to the TV, switches channels, again watch the news. Eve takes his fascination with television as a of intelligence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can see that it must be very important for you to stay informed of all the latest events.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I admire that in a person. As for myself, I find there is so much to assimilate that it can become quite muddling at times... Chance nods, changes the channel, watches a Mighty Mouse cartoon. Eve looks at him perplexed, then takes it for a and smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two uniformed valets, WILSON and PERKINS, await the limousines by the front door of the Rand mansion. Wilson stands behind a wheelchair. As the limo parks, Perkins an Jeffrey assist Chance into the chair. Wilson turns to Eve she gets out of the limo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good evening, Mrs. Rand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good evening, Wilson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I shall take the gentleman to the third floor guest suite, ma'am. Dr. Allenby is standing by.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, Wilson. That will be fine. Perkins and Jeffrey carry Chance in the chair up the step and into the house. Eve and Wilson follow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Once inside the house, Wilson takes over wheeling Chance. lady, GRETA, is waiting to take Eve's coat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, Greta. (to Wilson)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll be with Mr. Rand if I'm needed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, ma'am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Chance)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll see you after the doctor has a look at your leg, Mr. Gardiner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking around mansion)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I think he should examine my leg. Eve watches as Wilson wheels Chance around a corner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The doors open, Wilson pushes Chance into the elevator. A Wilson pushes a button and the doors close on them, a str look comes over Chance's face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looks to Wilson)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... I've never been in one of these. Wilson thinks that Chance is talking about the wheelchair

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's one of Mr. Rand's. Since he's been ill... Chance looks around the elevator.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Does it have a television?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughs)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No - but Mr. Rand does have one with an electric motor, that way he can get around by himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see. Chance again checks out the elevator.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long do we stay in here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long? I don't know, see what the doctor says ... The elevator stops on the third floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A hallway adjoining a large, glass-enclosed room. Eve pas through the hall, enters the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eve enters into a hermetically sealed area, set up with a the latest hospital emergency gear; oxygen, EKG machine, ray machine, transfusion equipment, sterilizers, etc. BENJAMIN RAND, wearing a silk bathrobe, lies in a king-si bed in the center of the room. A nurse, CONSTANCE, is attending to her duties in the room, looks up as Eve come in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good evening, Mrs. Rand.

dialogues.speaker: EVE
dialogues.text: Good evening, Constance. Ben Rand perks up as he sees Eve crossing to him. He is i his sixties, maintains an inner strength and dignity desp the sapping effects of his illness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with weakness)  ... Eve... Eve kisses him, holds his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Ben - I miss you so when I'm out... How are you feeling?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tired... And I'm getting tired of being so tired. Other than that, I'm doing very well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No headaches?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, it's been a good day - better than yours, from what I've been told.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (holds his hand against her cheek)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You heard?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I may be a shut-in, but I do not lack for news. I'm sorry you had to go through all that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, it wasn't all that bad, darling. We were fortunate that Mr. Gardiner turned out to be so reasonable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reasonable? Good, I'd like to meet a reasonable man. Why don't you ask this Gardiner to join us for dinner?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sits on the side of the bed)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you feel well enough for that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiles)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hah!... Tell me the truth, Eve - if I wait until I feel better, will I ever meet the man? There is silence from Eve. Rand squeezes her hand, turns Constance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Constance! I want new blood tonight, I'm getting up for dinner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But, Mr. Rand...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't argue, tell Robert I want new blood! (turns to Eve)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Ask him to dinner. Rand pulls Eve's hand close, kisses it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An enormous bedroom, filled with 18th Century antique furniture. DR. ROBERT ALLENBY dabs Chance's ass with a pi of cotton soaked in alcohol, prior to an injection. Chanc stands with his pants to the floor, looks to the televisi which is not turned on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The injection will ease the pain and swelling, Mr. Gardiner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I understand. I've seen it done before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, you'll barely feel this. It won't hurt at all. Allenby administers the injection, Chance reacts from the pain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You were wrong, it did hurt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a chuckle)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But not for long... As Allenby puts a band-aid on Chance's ass, Chance spots remote control for the TV on the bedside table. He reache out, picks it up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's good that there was no apparent damage to the bone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. I think so, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: However, with injuries such as this, I have run into minor hemorrhaging, which really isn't too serious at the time, but can cause secondary problems if not looked after.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see. Chance turns on the TV.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a look to the TV, then to Chance)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can pull your trousers up, now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as Chance pulls up pants)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just to take the proper precautions, Mr. Gardiner, I'd recommend we take you downstairs and X-ray your leg. (no reaction from Chance, Allenby takes a long look at him)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... By the way, Mr. Gardiner, I would like to ask you something straight out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (doesn't understand)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Straight out?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. Are you planning on making any sort of claim against the Rand's?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (after a beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Claim...? ... Oh, claim, that's what Thomas asked me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thomas? Who's Thomas?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thomas Franklin, an attorney.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An attorney?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (turns back to TV)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (suddenly very cold)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then you wish to handle this matter through your attorneys?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's no need for a claim, the garden is a healthy one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gives Chance a look)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I see... (warms up)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Well, then... You're a very funny man, Mr. Gardiner. You caught me off guard, I must admit...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (changes channels, sits on bed)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good, keep your weight off that leg, Mr. Gardiner. In fact, it would be best if you could stay here for a day or two, if that would be would be possible. Since Benjamin became ill we have our own hospital downstairs. I can promise you the finest in care, unless, of course, you would prefer to go elsewhere.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I could stay here. Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine. Would you like me to speak to your personal physician?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Allenby waits for Chance to say more, he does not. Finall Allenby picks up his bag, heads for the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stops by door)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll send Wilson up to take you for X-rays, Mr. Gardiner. Feel free to use the telephone, and please let me know if you have any discomfort.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (clicking changer)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I will. Allenby gives him a look, then leaves. Chance watches an movie of a man lighting a cigar. The man enjoys the cigar blows out smoke. The scene seems to 'sink into' Chance's mind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eve sits next to a roaring patio fireplace with a steamin cup of tea. Allenby comes outside, joins her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good God, Eve - you'll freeze out here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wanted some fresh air, Robert. How is Mr. Gardiner?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A rather large contusion, but I don't feel there is any serious damage. I'd like to keep an eye on him, though - I suggested that he stay here for a couple of days.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stay here? Is that necessary?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not necessary, but preferable. I don't think he'll be a bother, he seems like a most refreshing sort of man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, he is different... Not the kind of person one usually meets in Washington.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How true. Mr. Gardiner may be a welcome change of pace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's very intense, and internal, don't you think?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At times, yes. But that's not an uncommon reaction to such an accident. Actually, I found him to have quite a sense of humor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good. It might be pleasant for a couple of days.  (Eve puts down her tea)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Robert... Is there any improvement...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, Eve... I'm sorry. Eve is silent for a moment, looks out to the darkness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Sometimes when I see Ben I could swear that he's getting stronger... Something that he might say, the way he moves, or a look in his eyes - makes me feel that this is all a nightmare and that he'll be better soon... It's just so hard to believe what's really happening... Allenby reaches out, holds Eve's hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The elevator door opens, Wilson guides Chance in the wheelchair into the hallway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looks back to elevator)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... That is a very small room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughs)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes sir, I guess that's true smallest room in the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (glancing around)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. It seems to be. Wilson takes this as another joke, chuckles as he wheels Chance toward Rand's hospital room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CONSTANCE and another nurse, TERESA, stand by as Rand is being given a transfusion. Rand lifts his head as Wilson wheels Chance into the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Welcome to Rand Memorial Hospital, Mr. Gardiner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looks around room)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... I see. Wilson pushes Chance to the X-Ray machine, where the technician, BILLINGS, a Black man, waits. As Wilson and Billings help Chance onto the X-Ray table, Chance's face brightens up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I feel very good in here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure you do. This ward is air tight, I have a little extra oxygen pumped in, keeps my spirits up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. I like that very much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (lining up Chance's leg)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This won't take long, Mr. Gardiner. Please hold still when I ask. Chance stares at Billings, reacts to him being Black.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Billings)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you know Raphael?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No sir, I don't believe I do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. I have a message for him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Black man gave me the message.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I still don't believe I know the man, Mr. Gardiner. Now, hold still. Rand looks over as Billings takes the X-Ray.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aplastic anemia, Mr. Gardiner - aplastic anemia. Chance smiles to Rand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Failure of the bone marrow to produce red blood cells... Not a damn thing they can do about it. Oh, they can make me comfortable, prolong my life with steroid therapy and transfusions... And what makes my blood boil, what little I have left, that is, Mr. Gardiner - is that it's generally a young person's disease... Here I am, getting on in years and about to die of a young person's disease...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (still smiles at Rand)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. You look very sick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hold still, please, Mr. Gardiner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a laugh)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am very sick, and, as you can see by all this paraphernalia, I am very wealthy. I think I would rather be wealthy and sick than poor and sick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looks around the room)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I understand. I've never seen anything like this on television.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please, hold still, Mr. Gardiner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You too, Mr. Rand, you must stay quiet. Rand lays his head back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... We're prisoners, Mr. Gardiner - we're prisoners of tubes and technology.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I agree.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (flat on his back)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... You will join us for dinner, won't you, Mr. Gardiner?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (also flat on his back)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. I am very hungry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... So am I, my boy - so am I.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THURMAND, a waiter, and MARIANNE, a waitress, enter into Rand dining room carrying trays of food. The dining room immense, a 70-foot ceiling, huge fireplace. Allenby, Eve, Rand, and Chance (both in wheelchairs) sit around the tab Rand speaks slowly, with obvious weakness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know exactly what you mean. Today the businessman is at the mercy of kid-lawyers from the SEC. All they want to do is regulate our natural growth! It's happening across the country!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To everyone, I'm afraid. The Government controls are so restricting that the Medical Profession, as we know it, is being legislated out of existence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course! By kid-lawyers! Eve turns to Chance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Won't your injury prevent you from attending to business, Mr. Gardiner?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. It won't do that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Would you like us to notify anyone for you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. The Old Man died and Louise left. There is a moment of silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. I'm very sorry. Well, if you have any need for any of our facilities, please do not hesitate to ask.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you need a secretary?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, thank you. My house has been closed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. When you say 'Your house has been closed', you mean to say that your business was shut down?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. Shut down and locked by the attorneys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What'd I tell you? Kid-lawyers! The S.E.C.! Damn them!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hope that staying here won't be an inconvenience for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. I like it here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's good, Mr. Gardiner. Or may I call you Chauncey?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (agreeable to being called Chauncey)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. Chauncey is fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I'm Ben.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiles to Chance)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... And please call me Robert.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Robert. I will.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So tell me, Chauncey, what are your plans now? Chance looks around the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Does this house have a garden? Allenby gives Chance a look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do we have a garden? Hah! Tomorrow, Chauncey, you will see our gardens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see. I would like to work in your garden.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughs)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I know exactly what you mean. I sometimes enjoy puttering around myself, such a pleasant way to forget one's troubles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am a very good gardener.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A gardener! Well put, Chauncey excellent! Isn't that what a businessman is? A gardener? A person that makes flinty soil productive with the labor of his own hands, who waters it with the sweat from his own brow, and who creates a place of value for his family and community? Yes, Chauncey, what a brilliant metaphor -- yes, indeed, a productive businessman is a laborer in his own vineyard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, Ben. The garden that I left was such a place. Everything which grew there was with the labor of my own hands. I planted seeds and watered them and watched everything grow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (weakly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bravo!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I don't have that any more... (points to ceiling)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... All that's left for me now is the room upstairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, wait a minute, Chauncey you are young, you are healthy, for God's sake don't give up on yourself! You have to fight! You can't let those bastards keep you down! I don't want to hear any more from you about the 'Room Upstairs'. That's where I'm going soon. There is a long pause. Chance looks up, then smiles at Ra

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a very pleasant room, Ben.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughs)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I'm sure it is. That's what they say, anyway. Another period of silence. The servants bustle around the room as Allenby studies Chance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Allenby opens the door. Rand enters in his electric wheelchair followed by Chance being pushed by Wilson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... I don't know what you've heard about me, Chauncey, but I'm sure you know everything there is to know. Cigar? Rand holds out humidor to Chance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, thank you. (takes cigar)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No Ben. I don't know everything about you. Rand smiles as he takes a cigar for himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... No, of course you don't. Excuse me for being so presumptuous. No man knows everything about another man - however, very few are honest enough to admit it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That is so true. You're different, Chauncey... Quite different than most men.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, Robert. Rand lights his own cigar, then hands an ornate lighter t Chance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (picks up pool cue, weakly strokes the balls)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... You know, Chauncey, there are thousands of American businessmen, large and small, that share your plight. I've been concerned with the situation for some time now. Chance, not knowing to bite off the tip, tries to light t cigar like the man on TV. It will not light.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So I've been thinking about beginning a financial assistance program, Chauncey, to help out American businessmen that have been harassed by inflation, excessive taxation, unions and other indecencies... Allenby watches Chance trying to light the cigar as Rand speaks on, shooting pool as he talks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... I'd like to offer the decent 'Gardeners' of the business community a helping hand. After all, they are our strongest defense against the pollutants who so threaten our basic freedoms and the well-being of our middle class. Tell me, would you have any thoughts on such a program? Chance puts the unlit cigar in the ashtray, smiles at Allenby, then answers Rand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, Ben.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a smile)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reluctant to speak, eh, Chauncey? Well, I can understand that. When a man loses everything, anger has a tendency to block out reason for a time. Just give it some thought, work with the idea, I'm sure you'll have plenty to say in a few days.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I could give it some thought, Ben, but my leg is very sore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Oh? (looks to Allenby)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Robert, take a look, would you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some pain is to be expected...  (bends to Chance, looks at leg)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... And I think what would be best for the two of you is a good night's rest.  (checks watch)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... It's late, I'm afraid it's time for my patients to prepare for bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (puts down pool cue)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have common foes, Chauncey - kid lawyers and our physician!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I agree. Allenby laughs as he takes Rand's cigar from him, snuffs in the ashtray.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wilson stands behind Chance in the wheelchair. Chance gla slowly and inquisitively around the elevator. When his ey meet Wilson's, the valet breaks out in laughter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughing, trying to apologize)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Sorry, sir - I just couldn't contain myself... I knew you were going to come out with another one of your jests about the elevator... Excuse me, sir... The elevator stops, the door opens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wilson wheels Chance out of the elevator.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looks back as the door closes)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Hmmm... Elevator.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughs again)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Yes sir - elevator! Wilson stops laughing, becomes the stone-faced servant on again as he notices Eve coming out of her bedroom. Wilson stops wheeling Chance, stands stiffly at attention as Eve Chance talk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chauncey, I wanted to tell you how dreadful I feel about the accident today, but that I'm delighted that you are staying with us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, Eve - I like this house very much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... And Ben is just mad about you - you've lifted his spirits so - it's just... Well, it's just a real pleasure having you with us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben is very ill, Eve - I've seen that before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes... I know, Chauncey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I like Ben very much... He reminds me of the Old Man...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He does...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. Are you going to leave and close the house when he dies? Eve is not prepared for such a question.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Why... No, I don't think so...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's good. Chance smiles at Eve and there is a moment of silence bef Eve steps back into her bedroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Good night, Chauncey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good night, Eve. Eve closes the door. Wilson wheels Chance down the hallwa toward the guest room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eve comes out of the house, Jeffrey holds the door for he she gets into "RAND l." Jeffrey gets in and the limo pull away. Chance comes out of the front door, walking with a limp. His first view of the Rand grounds in the daylight, is taken by the extent of the greenery. An attendant, LEW hurries to Chance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you want a car, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. I would like a car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. Lewis goes to his post, picks up a phone. As Chance looks the surroundings, Allenby and Wilson, with Chance's wheelchair, come out of the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (frowns as he sees Chance walking)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chauncey, there you are. What are you doing on that leg?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's fine today, Robert.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shame on you, Chauncey - you should let me be the judge of that. (motions to Wilson)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please, sit in the chair. Wilson pushes the wheelchair to Chance, he sits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (checks leg)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I swear, Chauncey, between you and Benjamin, I've got my hands full...  (looks at calf)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Say, that is coming along, the swelling has gone down considerably... (pokes a spot)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Any pain here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Robert. But it's not bad. A limousine pulls up to the front of the mansion, waits f Chance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continues examining)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Benjamin has been hounding me to allow him to address the annual meeting of his Financial Institute today, but obviously, the strain would be impossible... How about here, Chauncey, any soreness?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hardly any, Robert. Lewis, the attendant, interrupts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your limousine, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reacting to limo)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Were you going somewhere?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, Robert.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Oh.  (checks leg)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... My God, I only wish that Benjamin had your recuperative powers... Anyway, the President offered to sit in for Ben at the meeting, quite a nice gesture, I felt. He's due here soon, I believe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Robert. I know about the President.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (mildly surprised)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Oh? You've heard?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. Ben called me. He wants me to meet the President.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stands)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He does, does he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Ben told me to be in his room at ten o'clock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why, that's terrific, Chauncey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do I know when it's ten o'clock? A long look from Allenby, then he looks at his watch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... It's five of, you'd best get on in there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, Robert. Wilson begins to push Chance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I would like to walk today.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hell yes - walk. You're meeting the President, aren't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gets out of chair)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, really? Allenby, a bit puzzled, watches as Chance goes into the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chance limps aimlessly through a hallway. He stops, admir large tapestry on the wall. A servant, SMYTHE, notices Ch appears confused, approaches him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: May I help you, Mr. Gardiner?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with a smile)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. I would like to go to Rand Memorial Hospital.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. There is another long pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Did you wish to see someone, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I would like to see Ben.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Mr. Rand, of course. Right this way, sir. Chance follows Smythe down the hall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rand is in an easy chair, dressed for his meeting with th President. The two nurses are working at the disinfecting table. Rand smiles as Chance is shown into the room by Smythe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chauncey, up and around this morning, are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Ben. My leg is not very sore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, that's good news, my boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're looking much better today, Ben.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hah! It's all make-up, Chauncey... I asked nurse Teresa to fix me up, I didn't want the President to think I was going to die during our talk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I understand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No one likes a dying man, my boy - because few know what death is. All we know is the terror of it. But you're an exception, Chauncey - that's what I admire in you, your marvelous balance. You don't stagger back and forth between fear and hope - you're a truly peaceful man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, Ben.  (looks at Rand closely)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... The nurse did a very good job, Ben. The nurses turn, look at Chance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wilson is at the head of eight servants lined up on the f steps. Two black PLYMOUTH SEDANS pull up and park. EIGHT in grey business suits get out. One of them, WOLTZ, goes directly to Wilson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good morning, Mr. Wilson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good morning, Mr. Woltz, nice to see you again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. How have you been?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine, thank you. (hands Woltz paper)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have an additional guest with us today, Mr. Chauncey Gardiner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reads list)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see... (turns to other men)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, let's go to work. The eight servants pair up with the eight men in suits an into the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
