dialogues.text: Allenby gets off the elevator, stands and thinks for a moment, then heads off down the hallway in the direction Chance's room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chance watches television as Rand speaks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, when I was younger I had thoughts about public office... But I found, Chauncey - that I was able to contribute more as a private citizen... of course, my wealth provided me with considerable influence, but I've tried, believe me, not to misuse that power... It's extremely important, Chauncey, when one is in a position of eminence, that he does not allow himself to become blinded to the needs of the country... The temptations are strong, and I've been labeled a 'kingmaker' by many, but I have tried to stay open to voices of the people... I have tried to remain honest to myself...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (changing channels)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see, Ben.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Maybe one day you shall find yourself in a similar position, Chauncey... Maybe one day...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two black limousines followed by a station wagon with sma holes in the side pull up in front of the mansion. As men from the first limousine and the station wagon jump out a take positions around the driveway, Lewis hurries to his post, picks up his phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The nerve center of the Rand Enterprises since he has bec ill. Four or five desks, all the latest electronic office equipment, three TV's with video taping facilities, count telephones. MRS. AUBREY, Rand's senior secretary, is at h desk, answers her phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes... Oh, very good, Lewis, thank you. Mrs. Aubrey hangs up, picks up another phone, pushes a button.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rand smiles at Chance as the phone rings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's here. (into phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Mrs. Aubrey? (listens)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine. Show the President to the library, we'll be along in a few minutes. Rand hangs up the phone, turns to Chance with a twinkle i his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's an old habit that goes along with power -- keep them waiting... Teresa brings Rand's wheelchair to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stands, very weak)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not now, Teresa. I'm seeing the President on my own two feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But, Mr. Rand...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (puts an arm around Chance for support)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shall we go, Chauncey?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Ben. That's a good idea. Rand walks slowly, clings to the limping Chance tightly a they leave the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Secret Service Men are seen in the background as Rand sto outside Mrs. Aubrey's office, leans in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Aubrey, have you received the papers on the Caracas agreement?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. They're ready for you to sign.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excellent.  (turns to Chance)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A good woman, Mrs. Aubrey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (seeing her for first time)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I agree, Ben. They shuffle off down the hallway. Chance smiles at the Secret Service men that they pass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Woltz and Wilson wait by the library door. Woltz takes a small metal detector from his pocket as Rand and Chance approach.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good morning, Mr. Rand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Woltz, how have you been?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (passes detector over Rand's body)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just fine, thank you, sir.  (turns to Chance)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you must be Mr. Gardiner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (passes detector over Chance)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just a formality, Mr. Gardiner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as he finishes)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you very much. Wilson knocks lightly, then opens the library door, Rand Chance enter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rand and Chance come into the Library and the President g to Rand with both hands outstretched.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (very weak)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Mr. President, how good to see you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's so good to see you too, Ben, you look terrific!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (barely able to stand)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not convinced of that, Mr. President, but your visit has raised my spirits...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I'm delighted to be here, my friend. I've missed you.  (guides Rand to chair)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here, sit down, get off your feet. As Rand sinks into the chair, Chance approaches the Presi with both hands outstretched.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good morning, Mr. President.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Hello. Chance and the President exchange a two-handed handshake. Rand, still weak from standing, catches his breath and introduces Chance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. President, I'd like you to meet my dear friend, Mr. Chauncey Gardiner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Gardiner, my pleasure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You look much taller on television, Mr. President.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Oh, really...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You will find that my house guest does not bandy words, Mr. President. The President gives Chance a look, then laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, Mr. Gardiner, that's just fine with me - I'm a man that appreciates a frank discussion... Be seated, please, Mr. Gardiner...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sitting)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I will.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (also sits)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, Ben, did you happen to get a chance to... Chance perks up at the mention of his name, interrupts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes? There is a beat as the President looks at Chance quizzica then he continues.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just wondered if you had gone over my speech, Ben.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Well?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Overall - pretty good. But, Mr. President, I think it's very dangerous to resort to temporary measures at this stage of the game.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, Ben... I...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I sympathize with your position, Mr. President, I know how difficult it is to be straightforward, the reaction to such a speech could be chaos.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's too big a risk, I can't take the chance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (again perks up)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes? Once again, the President gives Chance a puzzled look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perkins accompanies Secret Service Agent RIFF as he check out the third floor. Riff knocks on each door, looks insi then moves in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Allenby is searching through Chancels clothes looking for some sort of identification. There is a knock at the door Allenby pulls back from the closet as Riff opens the door looks inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh... Hello.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (entering)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good morning. I'm Riff, Secret Service.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Yes. Of course. Perkins watches curiously as Riff passes the metal detect over Allenby's clothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The President is worried about what Rand is telling him. paces, smokes a cigarette. Chance smiles through it all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... There is no longer any margin for inflation, it has gone as far as it can, you've reached your limits on taxation, dependence on foreign energy has reached a crisis, and, from where I see it, Mr. President, the Free Enterprise System has reached the breaking point. We are on the brink of another crash from which recovery might not be possible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's that serious, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm afraid so. The President now looks nearly as bad as Rand. He sits, t to Chance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you agree with Ben, Mr. Gardiner? Are we finished? Or do you think we can stimulate growth through temporary incentives?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As long as the roots are not severed, all is well and all will be well in the garden.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... In the garden?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That is correct. In a garden, growth has its season. There is spring and summer, but there is also fall and winter. And then spring and summer again...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (staring at Chance)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Spring and summer... (confused)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I see... Fall and winter. (smiles at Chance)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, indeed... (a beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Could you go through that one more time, please, Mr. Gardiner?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think what my most insightful friend is saying, Mr. President, is that we welcome the inevitable seasons of nature, yet we are upset by the seasons of our economy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. That is correct.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pleased)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Well, Mr. Gardiner, I must admit, that is one of the most refreshing and optimistic statements I've heard in a very, very long time. The President puts out his cigarette, rises.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Many of us forget that nature and society are one! Yes, though we have tried to cut ourselves off from nature, we are still a part of it! Like nature, our economic system remains, in the long run, stable and rational. And that is why we must not fear to be at its mercy!  (he smiles at Chance, who is absorbed in looking around the room at the books)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... I envy your good, solid sense, Mr. Gardiner - that is precisely what we lack on Capitol Hill.  (glances at watch)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I must be going.  (holds out hand to Chance)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Gardiner, this visit has been enlightening... Chance rises and shakes the President's hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. It has.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... You will honor me and my family with a visit, won't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. I will.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wonderful, we'll all look forward to seeing you.  (turns to Rand)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is Eve around? I'd like to say hello.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, she flew up to Boston for another charity event. She'll be sorry to have missed you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, too. Well, Nancy wanted me to send along her best to the two of you - and, Ben, I want to thank you for your time and thoughts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nonsense, Mr. President - I thank you for coming to spend time with a dying man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, Ben, I won't have any of that. Why don't you listen to your good friend Chauncey this is a time to think of life! The President clasps Rand's hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're right, Mr. President I don't like feeling sorry for myself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take care of yourself, Ben.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You take care too, Bobby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as he turns to go, a smile to Chance)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Gardiner... The President leaves the library and Chance sits back dow

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as the door closes)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's a decent fellow, the President, isn't he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Ben - he is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was quite impressed with your comments, Chauncey - he hears my sort of analysis from everyone, but yours, unfortunately - seldom if ever at all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm glad he came, Ben. It was nice talking to the President.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An aide, KAUFMAN, waits by the front door of the Rand mansion. As the President comes out, he speaks quietly to Kaufman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kaufman, I'm going to need information on Mr. Chauncey Gardiner's background.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (makes note of name)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gardiner, yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And put it through on a Code Red - I want it as soon as possible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No problem, Chief. They head toward the waiting limousines.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rand has an arm around Chance, hangs on for dear life as two of them walk through the hall. Behind them, Wilson an Perkins push empty wheelchairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (very weak)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... You know, Chauncey, there's something about you... You're direct, you grasp things quickly and you state them plainly. You don't play games with words to protect yourself. I feel I can speak to you frankly... You know what I was talking to you about last night?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (blankly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, Ben.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, sure you do, the financial assistance program. I think you might be just the man to take charge of such an undertaking. I'd like you to meet with the members of the Board, we'll be able to discuss the matter at greater length at that time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I understand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stops outside his door)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And, please, Chauncey - don't rush your decision. I know you're not a man to act on the spur of the moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, Ben.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And now, Chauncey, I'm afraid you must excuse me - I'm very tired all of a sudden. Wilson and Perkins leave the wheelchairs, assist Rand int his hospital room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as they go in)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry that you are so sick, Ben. The door closes, Chance limps off down the hall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chance, with a limp, walks down a pathway in the garden, admires the greenery. In the background, coming from the house, we see Eve.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (approaches Chance, calls)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chauncey!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stops, turns)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Eve.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your leg must be getting better.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. It's feeling much better now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good. I'm glad to hear that. (they walk together)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... How did you like meeting the President?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine. He's very nice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, he is. I'm sorry I didn't get to see him. They walk along in silence for a moment. Chance sees a hu greenhouse not far from them, heads toward it. Eve turns him, hesitates, then questions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Chauncey... Last night you mentioned an old man, that died.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Was he a relative? Or an intimate friend?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking at greenhouse)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was a very wealthy man, he looked after me since I was young.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I see... Your mentor, perhaps?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quizzically)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Mentor...? Eve takes his uncertainty as a reluctance to discuss the Man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forgive me, Chauncey - I didn't mean to pry. You must have been very close to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. I was.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry...  (getting more to the point)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... And what about Louise? YOU mentioned that she had gone, were you close to her also?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. I liked Louise very much. She was his maid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (relieved)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, his maid!... Stupid me, I thought perhaps she was someone that you may have been romantically involved with.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, no. She brought me my meals.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pleased)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course. Eve edges slightly closer to Chance. Chance edges slightl closer to the greenhouse, is fascinated by it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our greenhouse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pleased)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I like that very much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, so do we. Chance peeks through one of the windows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rand is in bed. Eve, Chance and Allenby are seated around him, the two nurses standing to one side. They all watch President's address to the Financial Institute on TV. Cha inhales deeply, enjoys the oxygen in the room. Rand is looking weaker. Every so often, Allenby casts a concerned glance his way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... And there are so many of you that have proclaimed that we are on the brink of the worst financial crisis in this nation's history. And there are so many of you demanding that we put into effect drastic measures to alter its course. Well, let me tell you, gentlemen, I have been conducting multiple-level consultations with members of the Cabinet, House and Senate. I have conducted meetings with prominent business leaders throughout the country. And this very morning I had an in-depth discussion with your founder and Chairman-Of-The-Board, Mr. Benjamin Turnbull Rand and his close friend and advisor Mr. Chauncey Gardiner... Rand perks up a bit at this mention. Allenby manages a sm once again looks at Rand, checking his condition. Eve loo proudly at Chance, who continues to enjoy the oxygen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Well, gentlemen, I found this to be a most rewarding conference... To quote Mr. Gardiner, a most intuitive man, 'As long as the roots of industry remain firmly planted in the national soil, the economic prospects are undoubtedly sunny.' Rand starts coughing, breathing heavily. Allenby and the nurses rush to his bedside. Allenby shoots a quick look t Eve and Chance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (motioning toward door)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse us, please.  Eve and Chance leave the room as Allenby administers aid Rand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gentlemen, let us not fear the inevitable chill and storms of autumn and winter, instead, let us anticipate the rapid growth of springtime, let us await the rewards of summer. As in a garden of the earth, let us learn to accept and appreciate the times when the trees are bare as well as the times when we pick the fruit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eve and Chance sit in silence on the patio. Eve's eyes ar swollen, red, she has been crying. She turns to Chance, reaches out, touches his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hesitates)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... I'm... (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... I'm very grateful that you're here, Chauncey... (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... With us ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So am I, Eve. Allenby comes out the door, his mood is serious, professional. Eve turns quickly, awaits his news.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sits alongside Eve)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Eve - this has been an exhausting day for Ben...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (anxious)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... But he's...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's resting comfortably now. There's no cause for alarm, yet... Mrs. Aubrey comes out of the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Gardiner, I have a telephone call for you. Sidney Courtney, the financial editor of the Washington Post.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (not moving)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you care to take it, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. Chance still does not move. Eve mistakes Chance's not mov for concern for herself. She puts a hand on his shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll be all right, Chauncey you go ahead with Mrs. Aubrey...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (rising)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Eve. You'll be all right. Chance follows Mrs. Aubrey into the house. Eve watches hi go, then turns to Allenby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... He's such a sensitive man, so considerate...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Aubrey leads Chance to a phone at one of the desks. three television sets are on, attract Chance's attention.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (picks up phone, looks at TVs)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SID COURTNEY, a Black man in his fifties, wears a rumpled wool jacket, smokes a pipe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Mr. Gardiner. This is Sid Courtney, Washington Post.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Sid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry to disturb you, Mr. Gardiner, I know you must be very busy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking from one TV to the other)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. I'm not busy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then, I'll be brief. I covered the President's speech at the Financial Institute today, and since the Post would like to be as exact as possible, we would appreciate your comments on the meeting that took place between Mr. Rand, the President and yourself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The President is a nice person. I enjoyed it very much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good, sir. And so, it seems, did the President - but we would like to have some facts; such as, uh... What exactly is the relationship between yourself and that of the First American Financial Corporation?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think you should ask Mr. Rand that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course. But since he is ill I'm taking the liberty of asking you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, that is correct. I think you should ask Mr. Rand that. Courtney doesn't understand but continues his questioning

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see. Then one more quick question, Mr. Gardiner; since we at the Post would like to, uh - update our profile on you - what exactly is your business?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have nothing more to say. Chance hangs up the phone, watches the TVs. Courtney listens to the dial tone, then puts the receiver down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to himself)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Typical - no wonder he's so close to Rand...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chance comes out of Mrs. Aubrey's office, notices the ser elevator.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hmmm. Elevator. He gets in the elevator.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chance looks at the row of buttons, presses one. He smile he feels the elevator move.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One of Mrs. Aubrey's secretaries, JENNIFER, waits with an load of paperwork for the elevator. The door opens, Chanc smiles at her as he steps out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (surprised to see him)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why, hello, Mr. Gardiner - are you looking for someone?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Jennifer gets in the elevator, the doors Close. Chance lo around the basement, puzzled. He had expected to be on th third floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Aubrey is at her desk, buzzing her inter-house phone Jennifer enters, Mrs. Aubrey hangs up in frustration.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't find Mr. Gardiner anywhere.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's in the basement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's he doing in the basement?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know, Mrs. Aubrey. Mrs. Aubrey grabs a notepad, leaves the office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Aubrey comes out of the service elevator, hurries through the basement. She checks: The boiler room. The electrical room. The photographer's studio (Eve is sitting for a portrait) The gym (Allenby is working out)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chance stands in the middle of the two-lane bowling alley totally confused. Mrs. Aubrey enters, he smiles at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Mr. Gardiner, I've been looking all over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Morton Hull, the producer of 'This Evening' just called.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I have seen that show on television.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course. They would like you to appear on the show tonight. The Vice President was scheduled, but he had to cancel, and they asked if you would be interested.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. I would like to be on that show.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine. They felt that since you had such close ties with the President, you would be a splendid choice.  (Chance nods, there is a pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Can I help you? Are you looking for something?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. I like this attic very much. Mrs. Aubrey gives him a look, leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AIR FORCE 1 passes through the clouds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The President sits on a couch in one of the compartments the jet. Before him, stand six of his STAFF, Kaufman included.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Gentlemen, I quoted this man on national television today he is obviously a financial sophisticate of some reknown.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir - we are aware of all that, but still, we haven't been able to...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interrupts)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's an advisor and close personal friend of Rand's! For Christ sakes, they have volumes of data on Benjamin!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Mr. President, we attempted to contact Mr. Rand, but he was too ill to...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (again interrupts)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do not want Benjamin Rand disturbed! You have other ways of gathering information than to trouble a dying man. Use whatever agencies are necessary to put together a detailed history of Chauncey Gardiner, if you run into problems, alert Honeycutt. (he stands)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll be in the office at seven in the morning and I would like to have it at that time. (he starts for door)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got to take a leak.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right, Chief. As the President goes to the Men's Room, two of the aides reach for telephones.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chance wears a velvet bathrobe, watches TV. Perkins lays a suit, shirt, tie, etc. on the bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I believe these garments will be quite appropriate, Mr. Gardiner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (eyes on TV)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. They are fine. There is a knock at the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me, sir. Perkins answers the door, it is Eve.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (entering)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chauncey...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (rises)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Eve.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chauncey, I just wanted to wish you well. I know you'll be smashing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, Eve.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And Benjamin sends along his best wishes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How is Ben feeling?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's tired, Chauncey - but he's going to watch you tonight. We'll both be watching.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's good. I like to watch, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know you do - you and your television... (a pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Good luck, Chauncey.  Eve impulsively steps forward, kisses Chance on the cheek Chance smiles at her, and Eve, slightly embarrassed, turn and leaves the room. Chance sits back down, watches TV as Perkins attends to his clothes with a whisk broom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Courtney heads a meeting of his four staffers. One man, KINNEY, a research assistant, sits behind a stack of paperwork, has a downcast expression as he listens to Courtney.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Gardiner is laconic, matter-of fact. The scuttlebutt is that he's a strong candidate for one of the vacant seats on the board of First American. But before we can do any sort of a piece on the man, we're going to need facts on his background... (turns to Kinney)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Kinney, what did you come up with?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (after a pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sighs, taps pencil on table)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Skip the levity, Kinney - what have you got?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (another pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... I realize this sounds banal but there is no information of any sort on Gardiner. We have no material on him - zilch... The room is quiet except for the tapping of Courtney's pencil.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The RAND 1 limousine parks in front of the station. As Jeffrey opens the door for Chance, MORTON HULL steps to t limo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Gardiner, I'm Morton Hull, the producer of 'This Evening.'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as they shake hands)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Morton. Hull takes Chance into the station.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Constance, Rand's nurse, enters Chance's room, goes to th closet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chance is intrigued by the surroundings as Hull guides hi through the corridor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course, Mr. Gardiner, the fact that you occupy such a position in the world of finance makes you ideally suited to provide our millions of viewers with an explanation of this nation's economic crisis.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you realize, Mr. Gardiner, that more people will be watching you tonight than all those who have seen theater plays in the last forty years?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. It's a very good show.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm glad you like it, Mr. Gardiner. Hull takes Chance into the MAKE-UP room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Constance is in the closet, searching through Chance's pockets, finding nothing. She takes out a small knife, cu label from one of the jackets. Quickly, she examines one Chance's shoes, copies the name of the shoemaker in a notebook. Constance hurries to the dresser, continues her search.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: COLSON, the makeup man, comes through the corridor carryi glass of water. He turns into the makeup room, goes to Ch who sits in front of the lights. Hull sits next to Chance briefs him on the show. Chance has his eyes on a TV monit watches the guest preceding him on "This Evening."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gives Chance water)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here you go, Mr. Gardiner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. I'm very thirsty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir - it's hot under those lights. Colson applies finishing touches to Chance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, if the host wants to ask you a question, he'll raise his left forefinger to his left eyebrow. (Chance watches TV)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then you'll stop, and he'll say something, and then you'll answer. On the TV, WILLIAM DUPONT, the host, wraps up his talk wi his guest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a last-minute dab)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, Mr. Gardiner, you're all set. Hull leads Chance out of the makeup room. Colson closes t door, then carefully picks up Chance's water glass, wraps in Kleenex, puts it in his overcoat pocket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: William Dupont introduces Chance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ladies and gentlemen, our very distinguished quest, Mr. Chauncey Gardiner! The BAND plays as Chance comes onto the stage. An audienc about three hundred applauds Chance as he appears. Two TV cameras move with him as he walks, with a smile and a lim to center stage. Dupont shakes Chance's hand, Chance hold Dupont's hand with both of his own.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Gardiner, how very nice to have you with us this evening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (showing Chance to chair)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd like to thank you for filling in on such short notice for the Vice President.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sits)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're welcome.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (also sitting)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I always find it surprising, Mr. Gardiner, to find men like yourself, who are working so intimately with the President, yet manage to remain relatively unknown.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. That is surprising.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Well, your anonymity will be a thing of the past from now on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (doesn't understand)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hope so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes... Of course, you know, Mr. Gardiner, that I always prefer an open and frank conversation with my guests, I hope you don't object to that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. I don't object.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine, then let's get started. The current state of our country is of vital interest to us all, and I would like to know if you agree with the President's view of the economy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which view? Applause and laughter from the audience. Dupont accustome parrying with his guests, asks again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come now, Mr. Gardiner, before his speech at the Financial Institute the President consulted with you and Benjamin Rand, did he not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. I was there with Ben.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know that, Mr. Gardiner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, let me rephrase the question; the President compared the economy of this country to a garden, and stated that after a period of decline a time of growth would naturally follow. Do you go along with this belief?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I know the garden very well. I have worked in it all my life. It is a good garden and a healthy one; its trees are healthy and so are its shrubs and flowers, as long as they are trimmed and watered in the right seasons. The garden needs a lot of care. I do agree with the President; everything in it will grow strong, and there is plenty of room in it for new trees and new flowers of all kinds. The audience applauds Chance's apparent metaphor. Dupont waits for it all to subside, then asks another question.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rand is in bed. Eve sits in a chair next to the bed, sque Rand's hand in excitement as they both watch Chance on television. Teresa, the nurse, watches in the background.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (over TV)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Well, Mr. Gardiner, that was very well put indeed, and I feel it was a booster for all of us who do not like to wallow in complaints or take delight in gloomy predictions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The President and First Lady are in bed together watching show.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gloomy predictions? That insolent son of a bitch!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (over TV)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's make it clear, Mr. Gardiner, it's your view that the collapse of the Stock Market, the dramatic increase in unemployment, you feel that this is just another season, so to speak, in the garden? The First Lady cuddles close the President, ruffles his h tries to cheer him up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chance answers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In a garden, things grow - but first some things must wither; some trees lose their leaves before they grow new leaves...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A small, dark room. A videotape machine is running. Also, machine is turning that records the harmonics of Chance's voice. TWO CIA MEN run the equipment, watch as a needle charts Chance's voice onto paper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (over TV)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Then they grow thicker and stronger and taller. Some trees die, but fresh saplings replace them. Gardens need a lot of care and a lot of love.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Franklin, the attorney that evicted Chance, comes out of bathroom brushing his teeth. His wife, JOHANNA, is in bed absorbed in "This Evening." Franklin sits on the end of t bed, watches the show.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (over TV)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... And if you give your garden a lot of love, and if you work very hard and have a lot of patience, in the proper season you will see it grow to be very beautiful... More applause from the TV. Franklin leans closer to the s

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (puzzled)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's that gardener!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Chauncey Gardiner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No! He's a real gardener!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughs)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He does talk like one, but I think he's brilliant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (over TV)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think your metaphors are quite interesting, Mr. Gardiner, but, haven't we seen seasons that have been devastating to certain countries?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The President and First Lady continue to watch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (over TV)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Such as disasterous winters, prolonged droughts that have wiped out crops, hurricanes that have all but swept away island communities? Doesn't a country need to have someone in charge that can see it through such crises?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... That bastard... The First Lady moves closer to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The TV, its volume low, plays in the background as Consta with a pair of tweezers, plucks a hair from Chance's pill puts it into a small vial.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (over TV)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't we need a leader capable of guiding us through the seasons? The bad as well as the good?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (over TV)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. We need a very good gardener.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dupont continues his questions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you feel that we have a 'Very good gardener' in office at this time, Mr. Gardiner? At the end of the question, Dupont glances over Chance's shoulder to look at the monitor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I understand. Chance turns to see what Dupont is looking at, sees the b of his own head on the TV screen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I realize that might be a difficult question for you, Mr. Gardiner - but there are a lot of us around the country that would like to hear your thoughts on the matter. Chance is still turned to the monitor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, yes. It is possible for one side of the garden to be flooded, and the other side to be dry...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Allenby watches Chance on television. The camera that cov Dupont in close-up has now pulled back, includes Dupont a Chance, both looking into camera. Allenby is concerned, h unsure of Chance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (over TV)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Some plants do well in the sun, and others grow better in the cool of the shade.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A group of ELDERLY BLACK PEOPLE sit in the lobby, watch " Evening" on an old black-and-white TV.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (over TV)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... It is the gardener's responsibility to take water from the flooded area and run it to the area that is dry. It is the gardener's responsibility not to plant a sun-loving flower in the shade of a high wall... During the preceding speech, Louise, the maid from the Ol Man's house, chatters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gobbledegook! All the time he talked gobbledegook! An' it's for sure a White man's world in America, hell, I raised that boy since he was the size of a pissant an' I'll say right now he never learned to read an' write - no sir! Had no brains at all, was stuffed with rice puddin' between the ears! Shortchanged by the Lord and dumb as a jackass an' look at him now! Yes, sir - all you gotta be is white in America an' you get whatever you want! Just listen to that boy - gobbledegook! There is a chorus of "Amens" as she finishes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chance continues.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... It is the responsibility of the gardener to adjust to the bad seasons as well as enjoy the good ones. If the gardener does his job, everything will be fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Audience applause is heard over TV. Rand claps weakly alo with the TV sound. Eve and Teresa also clap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Splendid. Just splendid... Rand looks up as Constance comes into the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damn, Constance, get in here! You shouldn't miss any of this! Constance hurries to Teresa's side. Rand turns to Eve.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm becoming quite attached to Chauncey - quite attached...  (Eve smiles)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... And so are you, aren't you, Eve.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Yes, I am, Ben.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reaches out, takes her hand)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's good... That's good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (over TV)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, Mr. Gardiner, from the sound of our audience, I'd say that your words are a most welcome respite from what we've been hearing from others...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (over TV)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dupont asks another question.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry to say that our time is running short, but before we close, I'd like to ask one final question. What sort of gardener, sir, would you be?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with confidence)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am a very serious gardener.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: More applause over the TV. The President pales.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Jesus... He rolls over in bed. The First Lady reaches out, puts a comforting hand on his shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Franklin holds a phone to his ear with one hand, shuts of the TV with the other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, I'll see you in twenty minutes. Franklin hangs up the phone, scurries around getting dres His wife, Johanna, sits grimly in bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (coldly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Business, bullshit! Going out in the middle of the night to meet that bitch in a bar...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sally Hayes is not a bitch - she's a damn fine attorney! I've got to talk to her about this Gardiner...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (turns over in bed)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, Johanna...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (cuts him off)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I said good night! Franklin gives up, hurries from the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Colson, carefully carrying his overcoat, walks with Chanc through the corridor. A delighted Hull walks behind them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marvelous! Just marvelous, Mr. Gardiner! What spirit you have, what confidence! Exactly what this country needs! Chance smiles at well-wishers as they continue on through corridor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The First Lady is snuggled up close to the President, caresses his body. After a moment, it becomes clear to he that he is not up to the occasion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Darling... What's wrong?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... I can't... I just can't right now... I'm sorry, dearest... I just can't... The First Lady looks at him for a beat, then turns, lies her back and stares at the ceiling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An 'in' meeting place for the upper-middle Washington, D. crowd. Thomas Franklin and Sally Hayes sit at a table, dr in front of them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... It didn't make any sense to me at all. I didn't know what the hell he was talking about...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He wasn't making a speech to us, Tom - he was talking to the masses. He was very clever, keeping it at a third grade level - that's what they understand...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah? Well, I don't understand what was up his sleeve when he pulled that stunt with us? What was he doing? And why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who knows...? Maybe the government had something to do with it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, Sally - I really feel like I've been had, and you know what that means, don't you?... It means that any political future I had is right down the toilet! The CAMERA begins to slowly move away from the table, the sound of Franklin's voice continues.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Jesus, the thought of spending the rest of my life as an attorney, that is really a downer... And, Christ, Sally, I almost forgot Johanna is starting to think something's going on between... Franklin's voice fades into the background hubbub. The vo of Kinney, the research assistant from the Washington Pos heard as the camera settles on a table occupied by Sidney Courtney and his staff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Sid, be reasonable - I've been everywhere, there's no place left to check!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Try again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure, try again - where? There's nothing, it's like he never existed!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Try again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sid, it's useless!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I said - try again. Kinney stands, shoves his paperwork across the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Up yours, Sid. You try again, I quit! Kinney takes his drink with him as he leaves the lounge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The household staff is lined up on the front steps, applauding Chance as he steps from the limousine. Chance accepts the plaudit, though does not understand the reaso As he nears the steps, Perkins and Wilson step forward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An outstanding speech, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: May I take your coat, Mr. Gardiner?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. Thank you, Perkins. Perkins nods, takes Chance's overcoat, allows everyone to enter the house ahead of him. Alone on the steps, Perkins quickly searches through the pockets of the coat, finds nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rand is in bed. Eve sits on the edge, looks warmly to Cha who stands nearby. Allenby prepares an injection for Rand, and occasionally glances curiously at Chance. Chance breathes deeply, enjo the oxygen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with some effort)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... You possess a great gift, Chauncey, of being natural. And that, my boy, is a rare talent, the true mark of a leader. You were strong and brave, yet did not moralize. I hope the entire country was watching you tonight, the entire country... Allenby crosses to Rand, needle in hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you, Benjamin, must be strong and brave for me. Turn over, please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (holds up hand)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In a minute, Robert - in a minute... Chauncey, I would like to ask a favor of you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Certainly, Ben.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Senator Rowley's widow, Sophie, is hosting an evening reception tomorrow evening honoring Ambassador Skrapinov of the Soviet Union... I think it's rather obvious that Robert won't allow me to attend, so - would you go in my place, and escort Eve?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. I would like to escort Eve.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good. Together, the two of you should create quite a stir - I can already hear the gossip.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with a blush)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Ben, really...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reaches out a tired hand to Chance - Chance holds it)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Thank you, Chauncey... Thank you very much.  (takes back hand)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... All right, Robert, I'm all yours. Eve and Chance quietly leave the room. Allenby watches Ch go, then readies Rand for the injection.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The elevator door opens, Eve and Chance come into the hallway. Chance looks back at the elevator for a beat, th the two walk quietly down the hall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stopping by bedroom door)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... You don't happen to have a tuxedo in your suitcase, do you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. Well, we can fix up one of Ben's for you tomorrow night. Sophie insists an Black Tie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a pause, softly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... I have very few friends, Chauncey... And Benjamin's friends are all quite a bit older... Eve gives Chance a long look, then kisses him on the lips She steps back, smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Good night, Chauncey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good night, Eve. Eve goes into her bedroom, closes the door. Chance heads his room as though nothing had happened.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kaufman and the five other Aides nervously await the President's arrival. The door opens, the President briskl enters the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good morning, gentlemen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as one)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good morning, sir. The President leads the way into the Oval Office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the President goes to his desk, Kaufman hands him a folder. The President sits, reads it quickly, it is very brief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Kaufman)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is not what I requested.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This information goes back three days. I want the standard file, you know that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right, Chief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So...? Where the hell is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We... uh, have been unable to come up with any information before the man appeared at Mr. Rand's home ... and, uh...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell are you talking about, Kaufman?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, we do have data from Honeycutt's sources, Chief - but it isn't pertinent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd like to hear that data, Kaufman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. Kaufman takes a clipboard from the man at his right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reading)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suits hand-made by a tailor in Chicago in 1918. The tailor went out of business in 1929, then took his own life.  ... His shoes were hand-made in 1928. The cobbler has long since been dead. Underwear, all of the finest cloth, factory destroyed by fire in 1938. The man carries no identification; no wallet, no driver's license, no credit cards. ... He carries one item along with him, a fine Swiss pocket-watch crafted at the turn of the century; so far they have been unable to ascertain where or when purchase was made. ... He has never dyed his hair. ... Computers have analyzed Gardiner's vocal characteristics; it is impossible to determine his ethnic background, they feel his accent may be northeastern, but they will not commit to that. ... Fingerprint check proved negative, no identification possible. (a pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... That's it, Mr. President. The President stares at Kaufman for a beat, then speaks i his intercom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into intercom)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Davis - I'd like my eggs poached this morning, please. A quick "Yes sir" from Miss Davis over the intercom. The President leans back in his swivel chair, looks at Kaufma

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... So what does all that add up to?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, sir - it occurred to us that he might be an agent of a foreign power. But, we ruled that out, as they invariably are provided with too much documentation, too much American identity... We, uh...don't quite know what to make of it yet, sir... But we'll keep on top of it, Mr. President - we'll come up with the answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with sarcasm)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I would appreciate that. The Aides quickly leave the office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chance is in bed, a bed tray on his lap, eating breakfast pile of the morning's newspapers lies at the foot of the untouched. The TV is playing, Chance watches as he eats. There is a knock at the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (without turning from TV)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come in! Eve enters, wearing a robe over her nightgown.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chauncey! Have you seen the papers?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, Eve. I don't read the papers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (moving to bed)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, it seems you've been described as one of the architects of the President's speech. And your own comments from the 'This Evening' show are quoted side by side with the President's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I like the President. He is a very nice man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sits on bed)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know...   (a moment)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... So are you, Chauncey ...   (another moment, Chance watches TV)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Do you mind my being here, like this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a bite of toast)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, Eve. I like you to be here. Eve smiles, moves a little closer to Chance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... You know, Chauncey... I want us to be... (with difficulty)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want us... You and I to become... close... I want us to become very close, you know...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Eve. I know that. Eve suddenly begins to cry, sobbing quietly at first, the losing control, the tears flowing freely. To comfort her, Chance puts his arm around her shoulder, nearly tipping h breakfast tray. Eve responds to his touch, draws closer, holds Chance tightly. Chance does his best to avoid spill his breakfast, keep an eye on the TV, and to comfort Eve. gives in to her desires, begins to caress Chance, running hand over his body. She kisses him, his eyes, his neck, h lips, his ears. Chance does not return the lovemaking, an Eve eventually catches hold of herself, stops. She lies quietly beside Chance for a time, regains her demeanor, t speaks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... I'm grateful to you, Chauncey... I would have opened to you with a touch, and you know that... (Chance,confused, turns to her)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... But you're so strong - I can trust myself with you. I'm glad, Chauncey - I'm glad that you showed so much restraint...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Eve. I'm very glad that you didn't open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know you are, Chauncey... (a pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... You conquer a woman from within herself, you infuse in her the need and desire and the longing for your love.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (another bite of toast)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. That could be true.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sits up)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... I guess I may as well be honest about my feelings, Chauncey, as I know you are I am in love with you... I love you and I want you... And I know that you know it and I'm grateful that you've decided to wait until... Until... Eve cannot bring herself to finish the sentence. She rise straightens her robe and moves toward the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stopping by door)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... I do love you, Chauncey. A knock at the door startles Eve. She turns, opens it to MAGGIE, the seam tress. Maggie carries one of Rand's tuxe

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, come in, Maggie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (entering)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, ma'am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chauncey, Maggie will alter Ben's tuxedo for you now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine. Eve leaves. Maggie stands by patiently as Chance eats his once-warm scrambled eggs and watches"Mr. Rogers Neighborh on TV.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Allenby is at his desk, searching through the Washington, D.C. telephone book. He finds a number, dials.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Thomas Franklin, please. (a wait)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is Thomas Franklin in? (a beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, this is Dr. Robert Allenby, would you please tell Mr. Franklin that I would like to talk to him? It concerns Chauncey Gardiner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Teresa and Constance work in a corner of the room. Rand i bed, very still, deep in thought.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The RAND 1 limousine pulls up to Sophie's house. Jeffrey opens the door for Eve and Chance. He wears Ben's tuxedo, is in a formal gown. The press is waiting, a couple of reporters, 5 photographers and a mini-cam crew from local station gather around Eve and Chance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Gardiner, what did you think of the Post's editorial on the President's speech?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling for photogs)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't read it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (surprised)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But air - you must have at least glanced at it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. I did not glance at it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Gardiner, the New York Times spoke of your 'Peculiar brand of optimism,' what was your reaction to that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continues to pose for pictures)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I did not read that either.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, how do you feel about that phrase, 'Peculiar brand of optimism?'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do not know what it means.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry to persist, air, but it would be of great interest to me to know what newspapers you do read.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do not read any newspapers. I watch TV. There is a moment of silence as the reporters digest this The TV Reporter smiles, questions Chance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Do you mean, Mr. Gardiner, that you find television's coverage of the news superior to that of the newspapers?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (flatly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I like to watch TV.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pleased) )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, Mr. Gardiner, for what is probably the most honest admission to come from a public figure in years. Few men in public life have the courage not to read newspapers none have the guts to admit it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're welcome. Eve and Chance walk toward the front door, leaving the newsmen to talk among themselves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've never seen anyone handle the media as well as you, Chauncey. You're so cool and detached - almost as if you were born to it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, Eve. The front door is opened for them by an attendant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Black Tie reception is in progress. The house is crow possibly a hundred guests, mostly foreign ambassadors and other such dignitaries. Eve and Chance enter, are greeted DENNIS WATSON, a State Department official.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Rand, how good to see you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Watson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looks to Chance)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you must be Mr. Gardiner, correct?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chauncey, this is Mr. Dennis Watson of the State Department.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (they shake)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Dennis.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A pleasure to meet you, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. It is. SOPHIE, an older woman bedecked with jewelry, approaches, embraces Eve.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eve, child! How nice of you to come.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Sophie. Sophie steps back, looks at Chance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And look who you brought with!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sophie, this is Chauncey Gardiner...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hugs Chance)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I've been just dying to meet you, Mr. Gardiner!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chauncey, this is Mrs. Sophia Rowley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (being hugged)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Sophia.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (steps back, admires Chance)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sophie, please - call me Sophie! Sophie pulls them both into the party, leaving Dennis loo after Chance as he walks away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as they go, to Chance)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You just have to let me introduce you to some of the exciting people here... Why, Pat Boone and his daughter may drop by later! They disappear into the crowd.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The President is hunched over his desk, absorbed in constructing a model airplane, a World War II flying fort bomber. The First Lady sits nearby, plays solitaire on a small table. The President glances to her, then back to h work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gluing the wing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... How are the kids getting along?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. Well, I just talked to Cindy this morning. She loves California, but to quote her, she says, 'The Secret Service is getting to be a drag.' I guess she wants her privacy...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh... I'm glad they're along with her, if you know what I mean... How about Jack?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I think Jack needs some time alone with you, darling... He's getting to that age, you know... He really misses you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah... I'll have a talk with him as soon as... A KNOCK at the door interrupts the President.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calls out)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Yes, come in! Kaufman enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry to disturb you, chief but we have new developments.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh? What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have word that the Soviets have put out a top priority alert for information on Gardiner's background. So far, they haven't come up with a thing - what's more, as a result of their eagerness, one of their ablest agents blew his cover, we have him in custody at this time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good. Anything else?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, chief - eight other foreign powers have put Gardiner under surveillance. We're around-the clock now, sir - I'll keep you posted. The President nods, Kaufman leaves. The President puts so more glue on the wing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sophie pulls Eve and Chance to AMBASSADOR SKRAPINOV and h WIFE. Skrapinov smiles as he sees Eve.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Rand. How delightful. Skrapinov kisses Eve's hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It seems like ages, Mr. Ambassador. (a nod to his wife)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Skrapinov. Mrs. Skrapinov returns the nod as Sophie introduces Chanc

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Gardiner, let me introduce you to our guest of honor, His Excellency Vladimar Skrapinov, Ambassador of the Soviet Union. Chance warmly shakes Skrapinov's hand with both of his ow

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stumbles over name)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello... His... His...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ambassador Skrapinov, this is Mr. Chauncey Gardiner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Delighted. Delighted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And this is Mrs. Skrapinov. Chance smiles at Mrs. Skrapinov as The Ambassador puts an around him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You must sit with us, my friend, we have much to discuss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I agree.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Eve)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How is my dear friend Benjamin feeling?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's doing as well as could be expected, Mr. Ambassador. He still speaks of the stimulating discussions he's had with you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, Yes. Please give him my regards.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (tugs at Eve)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, Eve. Let's let the men talk, there are so many people that have been asking about you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Chance and Skrapinov)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you two excuse me for a moment?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Regretfully, Mrs. Rand - I shall yield the pleasure of your company to others.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Eve. I shall yield too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll be back soon... Eve and Sophie leave. Skrapinov leads his wife and Chance their table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as they walk)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry we haven't met sooner, Mr. Gardiner. I had the pleasure of seeing you on television last night and I listened with great interest to your down-to-earth philosophy. I'm not surprised that it was so quickly endorsed by the President.  (quietly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Tell me, Mr. Gardiner, just how serious is Benjamin's illness? I did not want to upset Mrs. Rand by discussing it in detail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben is very ill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, so I've heard, a shame... As you know, we in the Soviet Union have the keenest interest in developments of the First American Financial Corporation... We are pleased to hear that you may fill Benjamin's place should he fail to recover.  (arrive at table)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Be seated, please, Mr. Gardiner. Chance sits between Skrapinov and Mrs. Skrapinov.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (moves chair close to Chance)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Mr. Gardiner, I wish to be quite candid - considering the gravity of your economic situation, shouldn't we, the diplomats, and you, the businessman - get together more often?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I agree, I think so too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To exchange our thoughts - what does a Russian know about business? On the other hand, what does an American know about diplomacy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I understand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I have noticed in you a certain reticence regarding political issues - so why not a coming together? An interchange of opinion? We may find, my friend, that we are not so far from each other, not so far!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (an engaging smile)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are not far...  (motions at nearness of their chairs)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... our chairs almost touch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughs)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bravo! Bravo! Our chairs are indeed almost touching! And we want to remain seated on them, correct? We don't want them snatched from under us, am I right? Because if one goes, the other goes, and then - boom! Boom! And we are both down before our time, you see? And neither of us wants that, do you agree?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I certainly do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. Tell me, Mr. Gardiner - do you by any chance enjoy Krylov's fables? I ask this because there is something... there is something Krylovian about you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you think so? Do you think so?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you know Krylov! Skrapinov pauses, then leans close to Chance, speaks soft in Russian. Chance, having never heard this language, rai his eyebrows and laughs. Mrs. Skrapinov remains impassive

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (amazed)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you know your Krylov in Russian, do you? Mr. Gardiner, I must confess I had suspected as much all along - I know an educated man when I meet one!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, it is very good!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, it is.  (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you tell me your name again, please?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (slaps Chance on the back)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ho! Ho! A dash of American humor! Vladimar Skrapinov!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. I like that name very much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And yours, sir - Chauncey Gardiner!  (in Russian)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How poetic! Chauncey, a name of uncertain meaning! And Gardiner, a bit of the French, a suggestion of a stroll through the flowers! A beautiful name, my friend! As he speaks in Russian, Eve comes to the table, taps Skrapinov on the shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (immediately rises)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Rand! You have returned to us!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only to steal Mr. Gardiner away, if I might.  (to Chance)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone wants to meet you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Eve. That would be good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shakes Chance's hand)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We must speak again, Mr. Gardiner, many times!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. As Eve and Chance leave, Skrapinov turns and nods to a MA standing a short distance away. The man, KARPATOV, hurrie the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes? What have you found?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in Russian)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have nothing on him, Ambassador Skrapinov.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (holds up hand, looks around)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quietly, please. Mr. Gardiner, for one, understands our language.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in English, softly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry, Comrade Ambassador.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean there is nothing? That's impossible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is no information available on the man before he moved into Benjamin Rand's. It has proven to be such a difficult task that it has resulted in the loss of one of our agents to the United States Government. Mrs. Skrapinov strains to overhear the conversation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But... Where was this man Gardiner before last week?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
